I spend much of my day using a CLI at work writing DCL, COBOL, and C programs and interacting with VMS - I can't for the life of me imagine how much more frustrating it would be if we used electromagnetic teletype machines!!

Dr. August Dvorak studied letter frequencies and the physiology of people's hands and created a layout to alleviate the problems he believed were part of the QWERTY layout. The layout he created adheres to these principles:  Letters should be typed by alternating between hands (which makes typing more rhythmic, increases speed, reduces error, and reduces fatigue). On the Dvorak, vowels are all on the left home row, the most used symbols are on the left, while the most used consonants are on the right.  For maximum speed and efficiency, the most common letters and bigrams should be the easiest to type. This means that they should be on the home row, which is where the fingers rest, and under the strongest fingers (Thus, about 70% of keyboard strokes on the Dvorak Simplified Keyboard are done on the home row and only 22% and 8% on the top and bottom rows respectively).  The least common letters should be on the bottom row which is the hardest row to reach.  The right hand should do more of the typing because most people are right-handed.
It's faster, less prone to errors, and more ergonomic (meaning less RSIs).

No benefit, unless you believe studies run by August Dvorak himself with extremely dubious asymmetric methodology.  Unless, of course, you want to be hipster and sneer at all the qwerty users for not being as edgy as you.  Dvorak seems pretty effective at that.

Don't laugh but in High School I used the TTY - Teletypewriter to search for Colleges in 1973! As a Computer Systems Operator I used a TTY in 1981/82 but then all interface with the CPU was by CRT for Operators but many Programmers used Hollerith Punch Cards lol. I worked on a Navy Base in PA for P3 Orion - Submarine Warfare and in 1981 we still had a Computer that used wire boards for a few jobs we had! Most jobs were run on Univac 901 & 1230 Computer Systems and we had a few Commodore Pets too. The 901 had 32K and cost > 1/2 million dollars! In 1982 I bought a Commodore 64 with 64K for $200 lol. Computer Pros laughed saying it was CHEAP but in 1990 my brother worked for NASA and told me the Space Shuttles had 5 Commodore 64 daisy chained together that ran the Spacecraft lol. Hardware cost dropped but software has gone up!

Teletype machines are the reason the the carriage return and linefeed characters are defined in the ASCII Standard ('' and '
' respectively). "Carriage return" literally means the action of moving the write head (or paper shuttle) back to the initial position of the line, and "linefeed" is the act of advancing a line. These two characters were the bane of a particular assignment I had to code up: a simple HTTP compliant server using the Unix Sockets API. I had to read and parse bytes from my socket and serve requests. To my dismay (and naivete at the time) the "empty lines" separating the HTTP headers from the optional body use the CRLF line-ending standard (both '' and '
'). This boggled my mind and took me forever to track down because the *nix-like systems almost exclusively use a single '
' to designate the end of lines (the superior way if you ask me). I learned an important lesson in reading and following standards to the T as well as never assuming anything in an unfamiliar system despite familiarity with another.
And that's how runescape was born.

I added a few more choices to the list. I'm also curious about what you used back in the day (80s/90s.) I remember when we made the switch from tcsh to ksh and it was painful. (This was before bash was widely available.) And while I was a big fan of xemacs for the GUI, I had to learn vi for the command line as it was usually the only full screen editor available. What are those things?

Emacs and  vim are text editors that can be run from the command line terminal.  Tcsh And ksh are command line interpreters for linux Pine and elm are text based e-mail clients. Lynx or elinks are command line web browsers. Screen or tmux are terminal multiplexers. advent/zork  and rogue/hack are games you can play on your terminal.

I was that way for awhile too; then I kind of got over it.  For the first year or so I used Linux, I virtually always had a terminal shell open.  Now I rarely do.  I mostly use it for running APT.  I'm a Mint 18 Cinnamon user, and the desktop is so polished that I can get just about everything done that way. On the other hand, sometimes there's the occasional task where the GUI just can't do it--like adding a sequential number to all the files in a directory.  That's a tedious manual task in any GUI, Windows Mac or Linux.  But it can be done in one line of Bash.  That's something that GUI has taken from us, we use our computers in such manual ways now.  That's the thing that grips new Linux users; the CLI is much more present and the power it has to truly automate tasks is revealed, when Windows is such a manual experience.

Sam Whelan mainly it's scriptability. If there is some process that you have to repeat often you can automate it on the command line where a simple task by hand in a gui can get impossible when scaled. For example but by no means limited to bulk file renaming or searching through tons of data. Instead of opening up hundreds of text documents and ctl-f ing you tell it where to look and what to look for and it does the work. Text interfaces can also take advantage of regular expressions which help you describe the format what your looking for even if you don't know the exact text. Like finding any text in a folder of files that is formatted like an email address, or phone number that only match a certain area code, ect. It's like being about to talk to an employee instead of only being able to point and grunt.

The one thing I wish could be made a little more transparent about the command line interface is what is available.  It's a foggy place, you can't see your whole environment, you have to know what's out there.

for viewers who feel like trying to use a command line interface on windows instead, here's some commands:  cd - change directory (I guess os designers simply agreed that that made sense) cd.. - change to root directory (same as going up a folder) dir - list directories dir/p - list directories and pause when the screen is full letter followed by a colon - switch drives  these also help if you like old computer games, since they're used in dosbox too.

While those letter pairs have key tops close together, they're separated by at least three type bars in the type basket, usually more. This is also part of the reason why the modern keyboard is staggered. Having the keys directly in line with each other would require the key levers to be stacked vertically and necessitate more space between each row, or significantly more complex key lever mechanisms (like the Smith Premier machines).

The source code for Colossal Adventure is available online, though originally in Fortran I'm sure someone has ported it. It is surprisingly short whereas I imagine Zork would be much longer, they were awesome games ... for the time. I believe Adventure is based on a real cave system in the US.

UteChewb You are right, Sir! From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colossal_Cave_Adventure  "In the game, the player controls a character through simple text commands to explore a cave rumored to be filled with wealth. Players earn predetermined points for acquiring treasure and escaping the cave alive, with the goal to earn the maximum amount of points offered. The concept bore out from Crowther's background as a caving enthusiast, with the game's cave structured loosely around the Mammoth Cave system in Kentucky."
